pullRequest.body:
This provides a variant that works on invertible elements of semirings, via `invOf` and `Ring.inverse`

This lets this be used on matrices.

The original lemma is from https://github.com/leanprover/lean3/commit/816c315b501481cea4edae1f9eecbd05c554fb61.


---

Thanks! I take your point about `one_div_mul_add_mul_one_div_eq_one_div_add_one_div`.

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9466838274/job/26079439155)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9466838274/job/26079438777)

```suggestion
  let _ := invertibleOfNonzero ha; let _ := invertibleOfNonzero hb
```
I changed my lemma names and now this all fits on one line.
What is the logic of having `inv_add_inv'` this way around and `one_div_mul_add_mul_one_div_eq_one_div_add_one_div` the other way around?
I don't think we should have `one_div_mul_add_mul_one_div_eq_one_div_add_one_div ` at all, but Leo did 7 years ago. Perhaps I should deprecate the long one?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: generalize `one_div_mul_add_mul_one_div_eq_one_div_add_one_div`
